title: FoolsFest 2024
text:
It’s a festive co-created campout. Think of it like a DIY festival.  No production company, no vendors, no paid entertainment, just US doin’ our thing and making silly foolish magic! 



A campsite where you can pitch a tent, hang a hammock, or park a vehicle to sleep in under the shade of beautiful California live oak trees! There are potable water spigots throughout Live Oak Campground and plenty of space, so feel free to spread out and build up. We will have “greeters” to help you find a spot and orient you to the campground when you arrive. 
The campground’s bathrooms are within a few minutes’ walk from your campsite, with running water, flush toilets, sinks, and showers. The showers are communal style, separated by genders - think gym locker room vibes, with many shower heads in one big open room.
An industrial kitchen is on-site, with a walk-in fridge, sinks, stoves, and greywater disposal. The industrial kitchen will primarily be available for those preparing food and beverage-related contributions for FoolsFest (see below), so please plan to store and prepare all personal food at your campsite, using your own cooking gear. There are no fires allowed in the campground, except for in the fire ring by the kitchen; feel free to roast your weenies there.
There are outlets at all the buildings at Live Oak, plus in a few other scattered power boxes. Extension cords are technically not allowed at Live Oak, so portable battery packs would be useful to bring if you have them. 



Whatever you need to meet your own basic needs that isn’t provided above! The two big things to bring are your personal meals and your shelter (tents, hammocks, camper vans, etc.). Other helpful items to put on your packing list: a headlamp, a silly hat, a yoga mat, first aid kit, earplugs, sunscreen, shower sandals, a portable chair, warm layers, and your sense of foolish fun!



This is a Pack it in / Pack it out event. Our motto is to leave it better than we found it! If you bring garbage or packaging we ask that you plan to pack it out when you leave. Help by bringing reusable eating utensils, plates, cups, and cloth napkins, and by removing products from packaging and cardboard boxes before coming. Water is available on site so no need for single use plastic water bottles – bring your reusable water bottles!



We are not selling tickets to FoolsFest, but we are encouraging attendees to make a donation in the range of $125-225 based on what you’re able to contribute. This will help cover the cost of the venue rental, sound system rentals, operations, and other supplies. We are grateful for whatever you can give!
Please donate via Venmo, cash, or check. To donate via Venmo please send to @Matthew-Robbins-16 and include FoolsFest2024 and the name of those you are donating on behalf of in the notes. To donate via cash or check you can either give to us in person or send it to Matthew Robbins, 930 Cieneguitas Road Santa Barbara, CA 93110.
If we end up in the green, any additional funds will be used for FoolsFests to come, such as to secure a venue for next year!



We have the entire campground rented out from Thursday, March 28 - Sunday, March 31. All are welcome to come and go whenever they please. Thursday is the setup day and if you’d like to come then to help out, please contact Erin or Mateo!
There’s no requirement to stay overnight, though many thrills, skills, and frills will only be revealed after dark ;)



There are many ways to contribute to FoolsFest! As a DIY co-created “festival”, this event is like a blank canvas for you to fill in with your preferred color of paint (or painted body part). There are three primary ways to contribute:
1) Share your passion! There will be no paid entertainment at FoolsFest - only us fools! If you’re someone who has a skill or passion you’d like to share, we’d love to hear about it. You could play music, dance, share a skill, lead a movement class, do some art, give a talk, put on a workshop, prepare food or drink to share, plan a game, and so much more - the sky’s the limit! Any and all forms of silliness and creativity are encouraged. 
2) Volunteer! Fools Fest is only happening because YOU will help make it happen. We’ll be sending out a survey form closer to the event to gather interest in specific volunteering duties, but we’re counting on you to pitch in when you see something that needs to be done. Is there trash on the ground? Pick it up. See someone struggling to put up a tent? Pitch in and give them a hand. Someone cooked you dinner? Clean the dishes!
3) Participate! Ultimately, this event is about showing up and just being present :) Enjoy and appreciate our time together, and the things other people are bringing! Get to know your fellow fools! Lend a hand! Tell a joke! Accept a gift! Learn a skill! Dance a jig! Explore Live Oak! Wear a costume! Participation can mean so many things, whether quiet or expressive, both behind-the-scenes and out front. We’re so excited to get foolish together!



No, you don’t have to bring enough for everyone, just aim for an amount that feels doable to you. People and events will be spread out around the campground, so there will rarely be 125 people all doing the same thing at the same time. Everyone should plan to take care of their own needs.



You are welcome to share your contribution at your campsite, or in any common spaces! An industrial kitchen will be available for food and beverage-related contributions, a Public House will be available for events, skillshares, workshops, or any other event-like contributions, and stages will be available for dance, performance, or music-related contributions. There is also a TON of open, free space throughout the campground - be creative, and use whatever space you’d like!
Reach out to Mateo or Erin to let us know what type of contribution you’ll be providing, and where you’d ideally like to set it up.  Spur-of-the-moment contributions are also welcomed and there will be a central message board where you can post last minute additions to FoolsFest.



Dress to express! Consider bringing fun, funny, unique costume pieces that make you feel great and may delight your fellow fools. We celebrate bodies of all forms, sizes, shapes, and functions. Nudity and Never-Nudes are welcomed alike! Finally, bring whatever you’ll need to stay comfortable in the Great Outdoors - closed-toed shoes and layers aren’t a bad idea!



In any gathering of humans, there is an inherent risk of picking up a nasty bug from someone. If you are sick and worried about getting others sick, you should stay home. We trust you all to take care of yourself and others!



No, though please make sure not to leave any food accessible in your campsite to avoid critters!



Yes, though please be mindful of your neighbors. Quiet hours begin at 10pm.



There are no pets allowed at FoolsFest.  However, reach out to us if there are special circumstances that make leaving your furry buddy at home a hardship.



Yes! Kids are enthusiastically welcome at FoolsFest. We hope to collectively create kid-friendly spaces (“Kidsville!”), activities, and contributions throughout the weekend. However, just like any trip with kids, FoolsFest with kids may take some extra preparation, planning, and diligence. For instance, there may be suggestive or mature themes present during the festival, depending on the music, events, performances, and other contributions offered. 



To maintain an atmosphere where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves freely and without worry, you must obtain clear and informed consent from anyone you are photographing before doing so. In addition, you must obtain clear and informed consent from those captured before posting any photos or videos on social media.

title: Event Info
text:
FoolsFest is a co-created campout filled with celebration, fun, music, and art in the great outdoors. FoolsFest is in the early stages of development, but we envision a gathering of creative minds who come together in the spirit of whimsy and playfulness to celebrate life and forge new connections. The magic of Foolsfest lies in the sharing, openness, and collective creativity and enthusiasm of its participants. We hope to see you there!


What: FoolsFest, a co-created campout


When: March 28 - 31, 2024


Where: Live Oak Campground, Santa Barbara County, CA

title: FAQ
text: It’s a festive co-created campout. Think of it like a DIY festival.  No production company, no vendors, no paid entertainment, just US doin’ our thing and making silly foolish magic!

title: FAQ
section: Will there be a central trash/recycling or do we take out waste with us?
text:
Will there be a central trash/recycling or do we take out waste with us?
This is a Pack it in / Pack it out event. Our motto is to leave it better than we found it! If you bring garbage or packaging we ask that you plan to pack it out when you leave. Help by bringing reusable eating utensils, plates, cups, and cloth napkins, and by removing products from packaging and cardboard boxes before coming. Water is available on site so no need for single use plastic water bottles – bring your reusable water bottles!

title: FAQ
text:
What is provided at FoolsFest?
A campsite where you can pitch a tent, hang a hammock, or park a vehicle to sleep in under the shade of beautiful California live oak trees! There are potable water spigots throughout Live Oak Campground and plenty of space, so feel free to spread out and build up. We will have “greeters” to help you find a spot and orient you to the campground when you arrive. 
The campground’s bathrooms are within a few minutes’ walk from your campsite, with running water, flush toilets, sinks, and showers. The showers are communal style, separated by genders - think gym locker room vibes, with many shower heads in one big open room.
An industrial kitchen is on-site, with a walk-in fridge, sinks, stoves, and greywater disposal. The industrial kitchen will primarily be available for those preparing food and beverage-related contributions for FoolsFest (see below), so please plan to store and prepare all personal food at your campsite, using your own cooking gear. There are no fires allowed in the campground, except for in the fire ring by the kitchen; feel free to roast your weenies there.
There are outlets at all the buildings at Live Oak, plus in a few other scattered power boxes. Extension cords are technically not allowed at Live Oak, so portable battery packs would be useful to bring if you have them.

title: FAQ
section: What do I need to provide?
text:
What do I need to provide?
Whatever you need to meet your own basic needs that isn’t provided above! The two big things to bring are your personal meals and your shelter (tents, hammocks, camper vans, etc.). Other helpful items to put on your packing list: a headlamp, a silly hat, a yoga mat, first aid kit, earplugs, sunscreen, shower sandals, a portable chair, warm layers, and your sense of foolish fun!

title: FAQ
text:
How much do tickets cost?
We are not selling tickets to FoolsFest, but we are encouraging attendees to make a donation in the range of $125-225 based on what you’re able to contribute. This will help cover the cost of the venue rental, sound system rentals, operations, and other supplies. We are grateful for whatever you can give!
Please donate via Venmo, cash, or check. To donate via Venmo please send to @Matthew-Robbins-16 and include FoolsFest2024 and the name of those you are donating on behalf of in the notes. To donate via cash or check you can either give to us in person or send it to Matthew Robbins, 930 Cieneguitas Road Santa Barbara, CA 93110.
If we end up in the green, any additional funds will be used for FoolsFests to come, such as to secure a venue for next year!
That said, we would really love for you to join us, so if you can’t make a donation, don’t let that stop you from attending. Your presence is the #1 gift :)

title: FAQ
section: When and where should we plan to arrive? And is it possible to come just for the day or do I have to stay overnight?
text:
When and where should we plan to arrive? And is it possible to come just for the day or do I have to stay overnight?
We have the entire campground rented out from Thursday, March 28 - Sunday, March 31. All are welcome to come and go whenever they please. Thursday is the setup day and if you’d like to come then to help out, please contact Erin or Mateo! On Sunday we’ll do an all-hands-on-deck cleanup.
There’s no requirement to stay overnight, though many thrills, skills, and frills will only be revealed after dark ;)

title: FAQ
section: How can I contribute to FoolsFest?
text:
How can I contribute to FoolsFest?
There are many ways to contribute to FoolsFest! As a DIY co-created “festival”, this event is like a blank canvas for you to fill in with your preferred color of paint (or painted body part). There are three primary ways to contribute:
1) Share your passion! There will be no paid entertainment at FoolsFest - only us fools! If you’re someone who has a skill or passion you’d like to share, we’d love to hear about it. You could play music, dance, share a skill, lead a movement class, do some art, give a talk, put on a workshop, prepare food or drink to share, plan a game, and so much more - the sky’s the limit! Any and all forms of silliness and creativity are encouraged. 
2) Volunteer! Fools Fest is only happening because YOU will help make it happen. We’ll be sending out a survey form closer to the event to gather interest in specific volunteering duties, but we’re counting on you to pitch in when you see something that needs to be done. Is there trash on the ground? Pick it up. See someone struggling to put up a tent? Pitch in and give them a hand. Someone cooked you dinner? Clean the dishes!
3) Participate! Ultimately, this event is about showing up and just being present :) Enjoy and appreciate our time together, and the things other people are bringing! Get to know your fellow fools! Lend a hand! Tell a joke! Accept a gift! Learn a skill! Dance a jig! Explore Live Oak! Wear a costume! Participation can mean so many things, whether quiet or expressive, both behind-the-scenes and out front. We’re so excited to get foolish together!

title: FAQ
section: I am interested in sharing food or drink at FoolsFest, do I have to prepare enough for all attendees?
text:
I am interested in sharing food or drink at FoolsFest, do I have to prepare enough for all attendees?
No, you don’t have to bring enough for everyone, just aim for an amount that feels doable to you. People and events will be spread out around the campground, so it will be rare that all participants will be doing the same thing at the same time. Everyone should plan to take care of their own needs.

title: FAQ
section: Do I have to share my contribution at my campsite?
text:
Do I have to share my contribution at my campsite?
You are welcome to share your contribution at your campsite, or in any common spaces! An industrial kitchen will be available for food and beverage-related contributions, a Public House will be available for events, skillshares, workshops, or any other event-like contributions, and stages will be available for dance, performance, or music-related contributions. There is also a TON of open, free space throughout the campground - be creative, and use whatever space you’d like!
Reach out to Mateo or Erin to let us know what type of contribution you’ll be providing, and where you’d ideally like to set it up.  Spur-of-the-moment contributions are also welcomed and there will be a central message board where you can post last minute additions to FoolsFest.

title: FAQ
text:
Is there a dress code?
Dress to express! Consider bringing fun, funny, unique costume pieces that make you feel great and may delight your fellow fools. We celebrate bodies of all forms, sizes, shapes, and functions. Nudity and Never-Nudes are welcomed alike! Finally, bring whatever you’ll need to stay comfortable in the Great Outdoors - closed-toed shoes and layers aren’t a bad idea!

title: FAQ
section: How can we help to prevent the spread of illness or COVID-19?
text:
How can we help to prevent the spread of illness or COVID-19?
In any gathering of humans, there is an inherent risk of picking up a nasty bug from someone. If you are sick and worried about getting others sick, you should stay home. We trust you all to take care of yourself and others!

title: FAQ
section: Should I be concerned about wildlife at Live Oak Campground?
text:
Should I be concerned about wildlife at Live Oak Campground?
No, though please make sure not to leave any food accessible in your campsite to avoid critters!

title: FAQ
text:
Is amplified sound allowed?
Yes, though please be mindful of your neighbors. Quiet hours begin at 10pm.

title: FAQ
text:
Are pets allowed?
There are no pets allowed at FoolsFest.  However, reach out to us if there are special circumstances that make leaving your furry buddy at home a hardship.

title: FAQ
text:
Are kids allowed?
Yes! Kids are enthusiastically welcome at FoolsFest. We hope to collectively create kid-friendly spaces (“Kidsville!”), activities, and contributions throughout the weekend. However, just like any trip with kids, FoolsFest with kids may take some extra preparation, planning, and diligence. For instance, there may be suggestive or mature themes present during the festival, depending on the music, events, performances, and other contributions offered.

title: FAQ
section: What’s the photo and video policy for FoolsFest?
text:
What’s the photo and video policy for FoolsFest?
To maintain an atmosphere where everyone feels comfortable expressing themselves freely and without worry, you must obtain clear and informed consent from anyone you are photographing before doing so. In addition, you must obtain clear and informed consent from those captured before posting any photos or videos on social media.

Feb 4, 2024

title: No stupid questions…
text:
Collaborative art from the first Zoom call



FoolsFest 2024 kicked off in style with a Town Hall call for questions, answers and getting excited!


We talked about the things that makes FoolsFest unique, the expansiveness of this canvas, inclusivity for all types of fools, building community, logistical questions, the production of a FoolsFest festival guide, sources of inspiration, and fun & games.


Participants on the call shared that they were excited for Silliness in Nature, Connecting Through Foolishness, Creative Expression, Reconnecting and New Encounters, Unique Contributions…and Chalk(!)


Here’s how you can continue the planning conversation. Check out and contribute to:


Spreadsheet of events and contributions that are already in the works!


Pinterest page for fleshing out our foolish vision.


Brainstorm board for bouncing around ideas.

title: Fools Fest…
text:
FoolsFest 2024 kicked off in style with a Town Hall call for questions, answers and getting excited!


We wore some fun hats, answered some questions and brainstormed, went over our list of Clown Coordinator slots to make sure we are covering all our bases, announced that we’ll be doing another site visit to Live Oak soon, and added to a list of questions for the venue manager.


Sam wrote a poem about it (!):


Fools Fest, Schmools Fest By Sam Arsenault
- written during the planning meeting about the planning meeting 2/21/2024


Fools Fest, Schmools Fest Uplifting Kosher Gruel Fest


To be catsup on a hotdog, bare on the plate, Exposed to the world, no bun to protect you from fate


125 will fill my desired vibe Ron de Santis will not abide


Some more signups will bring my smile up, But not as much as snow cones bring my BAC up


Super mega lux bathrooms, Toilets, showers, water and all


Full industrial kitchen, To collaborate and pitch-in in


Forest Stage, Schmoorest Stage I like sheds with all four walls


But believing is believing, And I’ll sure be sad when I am leaving
